summary:
“A journey of thousands miles begins with a single step” said Lao Tzu (c.600 BC). 
I like to read this quote at the start of a very demanding week for it reminds me that we can reach the sky and beyond if we take small steps in an orderly manner.

My journey in the space community started a bit by good fortune back in 2000 from my home country, Spain. At the time, I was most interested in bio-engineering and had just returned from an Erasmus programme in Greece. An opportunity for a one-year secondment within a French space company aroused and my employer thought of me as a candidate.  After this position, I returned to Madrid, then left again for France which was followed by an experience in the UK. Now I am settled in the Netherlands.

Some of the most exciting moments of my career so far took place during the launch campaigns and LEOP. Finally, the rocket lifts off. On board are the satellites you and many others have been working on for years, but all I can think about are technical questions related to my field of expertise: are batteries sufficiently charged to support the initial activities, will solar arrays deploy as planned? Perfectionism is my weak point…

I enjoy working in the multicultural work environment at the European Space Agency. I am native Spanish speaker fluent in two foreign languages both spoken with a Spanish accent. I am curious and like to learn new things or ways. I love to keep increasing my skills. I have recently completed a Master of Space System and Business Engineering from TU Graz University in Austria. After working for Telecom, Science and Earth Observation missions, through this Master, I discovered more about Space Exploration, and in particular Lunar Exploration…

As Neil Armstrong put it, this is one small step for man…
